quizName: Test for processors of personal data
introText: You can use this test to assess your company's compliance with the obligations of a processor. After submitting your answers, you will receive a report with compiled feedback on your answers and recommended measures based on them.

questions.question: Does your company process personal data?

choices.selectedText: In practice, all companies process personal data to some extent. Activities such as the collection, storage, editing and erasure of personal data all constitute processing. Personal data includes all information that permits a person to be identified either directly or indirectly, such as their name, telephone number, email address or home address. The General Data Protection Regulation applies to personal data and imposes obligations on parties who process personal data. More information on the definition of personal data: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/what-is-personal-data More information on the definition of processing: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processing-of-personal-data
choices.selectedActions: To be able to comply with personal data legislation, a company first has to understand what personal data it is processing and how. If you do not have a clear picture of the personal data you are processing, start by charting and identifying them. Review the personal data that your company is storing into various information systems. Do not forget to include data on paper.

questions.question: Has your company signed personal data processing agreements with controllers?

choices.selectedText: A processor's right to process personal data is based on an agreement concluded with a controller and instructions issued by the controller. The processor must conclude an agreement or other legal document with the controller, which defines the obligations of each party and includes the content required by Article 28 of the GDPR. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processors-responsibilities
choices.selectedActions: Good. Check that the agreements cover everything required by the GDPR. Companies should check that their contracts are up to date on a regular basis.

questions.question: Does your company's tool, product or service permit the controller to only collect and store personal data that is necessary for the purposes defined by the controller?

choices.selectedText:
A controller may only process personal data that is necessary for the purposes of the processing. To be able to correctly assess the necessary amount of personal data, the controller must clearly determine the reason why the type of personal data in question is needed. The purpose of processing helps you define which personal data you need to process. Personal data may not be stored just in case.

The processor must ensure that the controller is able to minimise the amount of data processed. The minimisation of personal data must be taken into account already when collecting the data. If you use a form to collect data, the controller must have the option to remove fields that are not necessary for its purposes. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/minimisation-of-data
choices.selectedActions: Go through the phases of your processing operation, such as collection, distribution and storage. Make sure that the controller can specify which personal data are necessary for the purposes of the processing.

questions.question: Does your company's tool, product or service permit the controller to minimise, update and erase the personal data it is processing?

choices.selectedText:
A processor has an obligation to ensure that the principles of data protection are built into the tools, products, applications or services offered to controllers. This means, for example, that the product or service offered to the controller provides the option to update and erase personal data. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processors-responsibilities

questions.question: Has your company drawn up instructions for erasing data or returning it to the controller when your customer relationship or cooperation with the controller ends?

choices.selectedText: When the service provided by a processor or other cooperation with the controller ends, the controller's personal data must either be destroyed irreversibly or returned to the controller, as instructed by the controller. You must also agree on the erasure of data in the processing agreement signed by the controller and processor. Companies should define the practical measures to be taken upon the termination of an agreement. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processors-responsibilities
choices.selectedActions: Good. Make sure that your personnel is trained to follow the instructions.

questions.question: Has your company drawn up a written description of its processing of personal data (i.e. a record of processing activities)?

choices.selectedActions: It is good that you have drawn up a record of processing activities. The document must also be updated on a regular basis.
choices.selectedText: The record of processing activities is often confused with the privacy statement. The record of processing activities is an internal document intended to demonstrate the company's compliance with its data protection obligations (while the privacy statement is a document intended for data subjects). The record of processing activities contains information such as the purposes of processing and disclosures and storage times of data. In some cases, the General Data Protection Regulation requires a company to draw up a record of processing activities in accordance with the GDPR. Recording the processing of personal data is a useful way to maintain an overview of processing even when a written description is not required by the GDPR. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/record-of-processing-activities

choices.selectedActions: Check whether your company is required to draw up a record of processing activities. Draw up the record in the manner you see fit. You are free to use the Excel template available on the website of the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman.

questions.question: Do your company or its subcontractors transfer the controller's personal data outside the EU/EEA?

choices.selectedText: For example, if a company processes personal data on a cloud platform provided by an organisation established outside the EEA, this constitutes a transfer of data outside the EEA. The General Data Protection Regulation does not prohibit or prevent the transfer of data outside the EEA. However, transferring data outside the EEA requires an appropriate basis for the transfer in addition to compliance with the other provisions of data protection legislation. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/transfers-of-personal-data-out-of-the-eea
choices.selectedActions: Great! You also need to reassess the situation on a regular basis. And do not forget to make sure that the controller has authorised you to use subcontractors.

questions.question: If personal data is being transferred outside the EEA, have you specified a basis for these transfers, such as an adequacy decision made by the European Commission regarding the level of data protection in the country in question?

choices.selectedText: An adequacy decision by the Commission is the primary basis for transferring personal data to third countries. If the Commission has not issued an adequacy decision, the company must specify a different basis for the transfers, such as the standard contractual clauses approved by the Commission. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/transfers-of-personal-data-out-of-the-eea
choices.selectedActions: In certain cases, the basis for transfer does not provide sufficient protection in itself. Various technical, organisational or contractual safeguards can be used to supplement the basis for transfer in some situations. Controllers and processors who transfer data must verify on a case-by-case basis whether the legislation of the third country guarantees a level of protection essentially equivalent to that ensured within the European Economic Area for the personal data being transferred. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/safeguards-to-supplement-transfer-tools

questions.question: Has your company assessed the risks caused to the rights and freedoms of the data subjects by your processing of personal data?

choices.selectedText: The controller and processor have an obligation to assess the risks related to the processing of personal data. The controller and processor must assess which of the data subject's rights and freedoms the processing could endanger, and what damage the data subject could suffer from the intended processing. The processor must take all possible measures to ensure a level of data security corresponding to the risk. If the controller has an obligation to conduct a data protection impact assessment (DPIA), the processor must help the controller with making the assessment and deliver any information needed by the controller for the assessment. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/risk-assessment-and-data-protection-planning
choices.selectedActions: Make sure that the risks related to processing and the adequacy of safeguards are reassessed on a regular basis.

More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/risk-assessment-and-data-protection-planning

questions.question: Has your company implemented adequate measures to ensure the availability of personal data?

choices.selectedText:
The availability of personal data means that it is available for use when needed. The availability of personal data can be compromised by incidents such as blackouts, denial-of-service attacks or ransomware. One way of ensuring the availability of data is to make backups. The necessity and adequacy of safeguards must be assessed in relation to the conditions and risks of the processing.

The effectiveness of your measures taken to safeguard the availability of data should be in proportion to the potential harm caused by he disappearance of data or a service outage. For example, an outage in a hospital information system can cause much more serious harm to the data subject than the crashing of a hair-dresser's booking system.

questions.question: What will you do if you suspect that a personal data breach has been committed against the controller's personal data?

choices.option: Instructions have been drawn up for the eventuality of a personal data breach
choices.selectedText: The processor has a duty to notify the controller without undue delay after becoming aware of a personal data breach. The processor can notify the supervisory authority and data subjects of a personal data breach on behalf of the controller if this has been clearly agreed in the agreement between the processor and controller. However, the controller remains responsible for the fulfilment of the notification obligation. A controller is required to prepare for possible personal data breaches by drawing up instructions. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processors-responsibilities
choices.selectedActions: Great! Make sure that your personnel is trained to follow the instructions. The instructions must also be updated on a regular basis.

questions.question: Has your company appointed a Data Protection Officer (DPO)?

choices.selectedActions: Great! Familiarise yourselves with the duties of a DPO in detail. You can subscribe to the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman's newsletter for data protection officers: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers
choices.selectedText: You must appoint a DPO if you process sensitive data on a large scale, monitor people regularly, systematically and on a large scale, or your organisation is a public body (with the exception of the courts). It can be useful to appoint a DPO even if you are not required to do so. Read more about the appointment and duties of a DPO: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers

choices.selectedActions: Read more about the appointment and duties of a DPO. Appoint a DPO if you meet the conditions. Even if you do not appoint an official DPO, you should still designate someone in charge of data protection matters in your company. Tasks related to data protection are more likely to get done if you assign responsibility for them to specific individuals. Your company still bears the final responsibility for compliance with data protection requirements, however.
